body:
@navis the point of the IAE and ISE exceptions is that it allows you to use formatted strings, so rather than doing:

`throw new IAE("first argument should be string type but got " + value.type() + " type");`

You can do:

`throw new IAE("first argument should be string type but got %s type", value.type());`

which is preferred in Druid.

@gianm we have seen 700 000 dangling direct byte buffers on historical nodes, presumably because of these leaks. It leads to GC issues and OOMs, i. e. instability. At Metamarkets are going to use it with 0.9.2 anyway. That is why we are pretty much indifferent is it backported or not, as long as it is already in master (0.9.3 onwards).

I got this is specialized version for bitmap index not like what I've commented above. So forget what I've said.

Revisiting this: it looks like the idea is that VirtualColumn is something that creates special ObjectColumnSelectors from CursorSelectorFactorys. I'm attempting to consider how to fit it in amongst existing abstractions we have, which I think is really important. Too many abstractions gets too confusing and unmaintainable.

Thinking out loud, we have:
- DimensionSpec, used for creating DimensionSelectors from CursorSelectorFactorys, which provide access to (possibly transformed / filtered) values and to the dictionary (if no transformation)
- ExtractionFn, used for transforming single values to strings. #3091 would add support for transforming multiple values to strings.
- AggregatorFactory, used for applying aggregation functions on CursorSelectorFactorys; can read anything and return anything.
- Expressions, used for creating NumericColumnSelectors from CursorSelectorFactorys, added in #2783.

Can we combine VirtualColumns and expressions? i.e. would it make sense, on CursorSelectorFactory, to get rid of:

``` java
NumericColumnSelector makeMathExpressionSelector(String expression)
```

and instead, add:

``` java
ObjectColumnSelector makeObjectColumnSelector(VirtualColumn virtualColumn)
```

I think that'd work for the map use case mentioned in the PR description as well as math expressions. For expressions, instead of `csf.makeMathExpressionSelector(expr)` a caller would do `makeObjectColumnSelector(new ExpressionVirtualColumn(expr))`. The returned ObjectColumnSelector would have classOfObject() as Number.class. Maybe also call VirtualColumns "ObjectSelectorSpecs" to draw attention to the similarity between them and DimensionSpecs.

I think this could make sense if it's possible to have a virtual column impl of making a math expression selector. This, I guess, would involve calling `makeObjectColumnSelector(foo)` on all the identifiers "foo" that the expression uses and then doing something reasonable with that. Could also help reduce code duplication in the column selector factories.

I haven't totally thought this through but if it works it sounds good to me‚Ä¶
üëç

@niketh when the MM shuts down, is the lock for a ingesting datasource released? Although I do not know much, but there seems a lock mechanism. If the MM shuts down and the yarn job still need to keep running, should there be a mechanism to make sure the lock mechanism works and another MM take over the running yarn job related ingest task? If there is not such mechanism I suggest we just kill the related yarn job when MM shutdown. And provide a configuration to disable this mechanism if desired.

I think this could also be related to the zero-filling feature which, as far as I know, dose not fill zeros between disjoint segments at the moment, but does for only missing values in a single segment. Does this issue cover only expressions or more general idea of how to treat missing values such as the zero-filling?
we are having issues with garbage collection pauses and occasional OOMs in Druid 0.9.1.1 and would love it if this fix were to make it into the 0.9.2 release
Ok, I will try to fix this issue

lol, I was checking out the code and noticed this. Those Googlers can be funny sometimes.

``` java
// close. this word no longer has any meaning to me.
```

Guava is ASL2, so I think it's fine to copy some stuff from there into Druid if it is simple code that saves a lot of headaches. We should just note in comments what version of Guava it came from and add something to NOTICE.
Also note in comments why we're doing this (avoiding potential guava conflicts in embedded situations like hadoop).
Or: alternative: confirm if the stuff in other-hadoop.md is a good workaround. Then we don't need to copy code from Guava, we just need to educate users better.
I think some users may not be trying those tips before concluding that something is unfixable.

Okay, based on recent comments from @leventov and @sascha-coenen the balance may shift to including this in 0.9.2. Especially since we already decided to upgrade Guice for 0.9.2 in #3222, and we already expect some people to need to adjust hadoop configs there.

I'm soft üëç  on including in 0.9.2-rc2. If nobody disagrees then IMO we should do it and just be on the lookout for people reporting hadoop issues with that version. We can also run it through the hadoop testing system we have been building here.
@navis we can take another look after rebased; #2836 is committed.

@jaehc IMO this issue is just about null handling for math expressions. If you want different behavior for zero filling in timeseries that could be a separate issue. Mostly since the code paths are not really very related.
@leventov any further comments?
@gianm no, LGTM.
@leventov @drcrallen @b-slim replaced null with empty map, added a test, and added more details to the post-populate log message.
I also changed the lines counter to an int from a long, and added a check for overflow, because we can't store more than int.maxvalue entries in a map anyway.
Also updated docs.
That's exactly how we use it internally. We have a smaller cluster that collects metrics for Kafka samba spark druid and all the other microservices.
*samza... phone autocorrect is being silly
I would rather label this a blocker for 0.9.3 and assume the review will be OK or minimal.

rebased on master

I've read this just now and not certain that I've understood fully. But one thing I can tell is that this is the first version that made nine months ago even before math expressions introduced, so virtual column is just a object column selector in here. But with expression and #2836, we can use it as any type(dimension/float/long/object) of selectors (one of the main following issue).
Or we can replace all of the "String columnName" parameters for ColumnSelectorFactory with "VirtualColumn vc". But it looks huge work and also will introduce backward compatibility issue.
Even we can reference VC in VC, which is hard to express with single vc parameter of factory method.

We _could_ (although we don't have to) also change the "expression" field on aggregators like longSum into something that takes VirtualColumn rather than a String. Then you could sum not just over expressions but also over any other kind of virtual column that returns numbers.
Ah, I see, for "we can reference VC in VC", giving them names and passing them to makeCursors makes it easier to do that, I guess.

I also thought of removing Sequence several times(even made a patch) but in some micro test comparing MergeSequence and MergeIterable, I've seen the former outperformed the latter. So I just let it go.
@b-slim https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/3654

in response to @cheddar , reason for the static method being in a separate class is to allow accessing the "protected" method from hadoop FileSystem class. That is why HadoopFsWrapper is put in "org.apache.hadoop.fs" package instead of usual "io.druid..."

@nishantmonu51 if they are needed then I would just take the change and let it be backward incompatible given that it is test code. I will update things on my side to work with the changes.

:+1:

We were passing multiple versions of Jackson libraries. I stopped passing multiple versions and then the problem is fixed.

@onlychoice index task shouldn't leave intermediate files behind. What directory is that, and what is contained in those directories? They look like segments to me. Is that your deep storage directory?
minor cleanup, otherwise üëç LGTM
@dclim fixed, thanks

@gianm on the semver thing.  Generally, we tend to do backwards incompatible changes through an increment of the minor version right now because we are still "0.x".  I consider this us still following a form of semver.  

I intended the "honor semver" comment to basically just reflect to how we version everything else.  If your comment is that we don't have great documentation for how we handle semver, then I think that we should update the version page (http://druid.io/docs/latest/development/versioning.html) instead of hiding it here.  I will go ahead and add a link to that from here though.
Minor cleanup, otherwise LGTM üëç
@cheddar, good point, I forgot about that page. Cross links between the two pages is good enough for me.

```
[ERROR] Failed to execute goal org.apache.maven.plugins:maven-checkstyle-plugin:2.17:check (validate) on project druid: Execution validate of goal org.apache.maven.plugins:maven-checkstyle-plugin:2.17:check failed: An API incompatibility was encountered while executing org.apache.maven.plugins:maven-checkstyle-plugin:2.17:check: java.lang.UnsupportedClassVersionError: com/puppycrawl/tools/checkstyle/api/CheckstyleException : Unsupported major.minor version 52.0
```

Maybe the newer checkstyle doesn't support java7, will look into that.

@knoguchi It'd actually be really nice if we could move out the protoBuf stuff into its own extension, similar to the extensions for the other formats that Druid supports. I think it'll be much easier to maintain and update versions in the future this way
@knoguchi this feature is great. Same question as I had in your other PR, how do you feel about moving Protobuf into its own extension?
Generally I'm üëç  on the changes. I made some minor comments but given this is an extension, and if there's been some basic testing on things, I think we should get this in for 0.9.3.

I like that idea.  Let me work on the Protobuf3 extension instead of making changes here.
Once I finish it the current Protobuf2 feature needs deprecation warning, and phase out eventually.
rebased
Downgraded to Checkstyle 6.19, which supports jdk7.
@leventov i get the mismatch between the size/count of entries but not sure what you mean by both onheap and offheap ?
@b-slim as it is configured to cache that many entries it effectively caches _every_ entry. So it keeps _all_ entries on-heap (in cache) and off-heap.
@gianm maybe activate different versions of checkstyle depending on the build jdk?
@leventov I don't see a really compelling reason to do that rather than just using the same version for both jdks.
@jon-wei I fixed those names (no idea how that happened). I added some explanation about the difference between `doubleMax` and `doubleGreatest`. And I rebased on master.
Merging, since the only change since two üëçs was to fix the jdk7 issue.

@lanzelot1989 this is a fairly common use case for Druid, usually people do things like:
- route metrics through Kafka and into Druid
- do alerting on thresholds (like avg query time > X) by polling Druid and alerting based on results of queries
- use the approximate histogram feature to compute medians and percentiles

Many Druid users actually use Druid to analyze execution times of Druid queries by feeding Druid metrics into Druid. (say that 10 times fast)

Closing this, but please follow up on the mailing list if you have further questions.
